projects.title: Stadium Suite Tablet
projects.description: A premium in-suite digital experience allowing guests to control the TV, order food, and request assistance.

content.content: Project Overview

Baltimore Ravens approached us to enhance the premium suite experience inside their stadium. Suite guests often juggle watching the live match, ordering food, adjusting TV settings, and calling attendants ‚Äî all through scattered, manual touchpoints.
Our objective was to unify all these experiences into one seamless digital interface.

The solution was a dedicated in-suite tablet, designed to give guests total control of their environment: media, food, services, and fan engagement features. My responsibility covered the entire UX flow ‚Äî from wireframes to polished UI.
Problem & Opportunity

Premium suite guests expect convenience, speed, and comfort ‚Äî but their current experience involved:
‚Ä¢ Slow food & beverage ordering
‚Ä¢ Confusing TV controls
‚Ä¢ Inconsistent access to attendants
‚Ä¢ No centralized interface for services
‚Ä¢ Missing out on highlights or game insights
Opportunity: To design a premium, unified, intuitive tablet experience that lets guests enjoy the game without interruptions and enhances the Ravens‚Äô hospitality offering.
Goals & Success Criteria

Our goals were clear:
‚Ä¢ Deliver a single digital hub for all suite services
‚Ä¢ Make TV control effortless and fast
‚Ä¢ Reduce wait times for food, beverages & assistance
‚Ä¢ Support real-time match engagement through live streams & highlights
‚Ä¢ Create a luxurious visual identity aligned with the Ravens brand
Process Overview

A structured approach ensured clarity and speed:
üîç Research
üóÇ Information Architecture
‚úèÔ∏è Wireframes
üé® High-Fidelity UI

Each stage helped refine interactions, reduce friction, and craft a premium experience suitable for a stadium environment.
Research & Key Insights
Based on stakeholder interviews, suite visit observations, and competitor benchmarking, we identified several core insights:

‚Ä¢ Guests want to interact quickly and return to watching the game.
‚Ä¢ Stadium suites have low lighting, requiring a dark, high-contrast UI.
‚Ä¢ Large touch targets are essential due to movement and multitasking.
‚Ä¢ Ordering should be fast, with minimal customization steps.
‚Ä¢ Service requests must be instant, without searching through menus.
User Flow Diagram
Home ‚Üí TV Controls ‚Üí Food & Beverages ‚Üí Merchandise Shop ‚Üí Service Requests ‚Üí Settings
The flow is intentionally linear and shallow to ensure guests reach any function within 1‚Äì2 taps.
Information Architecture

The structure keeps navigation familiar and predictable:

‚Ä¢ Home
‚Ä¢ TV (Live Match, Highlights, Channels)
‚Ä¢ Food & Beverages (Snacks, Drinks)
‚Ä¢ Merchandise (Jerseys, Caps)
‚Ä¢ Service Requests (Attendant, Valet)
‚Ä¢ Settings
Wireframes (Low-Fi)

Wireframes focused on primary navigation layout, quick access touchpoints, and visual hierarchy. Early testing validated that users preferred large buttons, high-contrast layouts, and dedicated shortcuts for TV and ordering.
https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1581291518633-83b4ebd1d83e?q=80&w=2070&auto=format&fit=crop
content.caption: Initial low-fidelity sketches of the interface

content.content: Final UI (High-Fidelity Mockups)
The final UI blends Ravens branding with a luxurious digital aesthetic.
Home Screen
A central hub with clear categories, large tiles, and bold visuals to guide users quickly.
https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1611162617474-5b21e879e113?q=80&w=1974&auto=format&fit=crop
content.caption: Home Screen UI

content.content: TV Controls
Full media control with options for live match, highlights, multi-camera angles, and entertainment channels. Designed with tactile buttons and clarity in motion.
Food & Beverage Ordering
Full-screen item cards, vivid photography, quick add-to-cart interactions, and streamlined customization.
Key Design Decisions

1. Dark, premium interface: Matches suite lighting and reduces glare.
2. Large, comfortable touch targets: Ensures effortless use even while multitasking.
3. High-contrast action buttons: Increases accessibility.
4. One-tap service interactions: Removes friction during high-engagement moments.
5. Modular card layout: Makes navigation predictable.
Outcome & Impact

The final tablet interface created a significantly smoother and elevated suite experience. Outcomes included faster ordering processes, reduced confusion with TV controls, and higher guest engagement during live games. Stakeholders responded positively, noting the system‚Äôs potential to set a new hospitality standard inside the stadium.

projects.title: Nova Financial
projects.description: A comprehensive dashboard for modern financial tracking.

content.content: The Challenge
Nova Financial needed a complete overhaul of their legacy tracking system. The goal was to reduce the time it takes for users to analyze their monthly spend by 50%.
https://picsum.photos/id/2/800/600
content.caption: Initial wireframes and sketches

content.content: Design System
We established a strict 8pt grid system and a color palette inspired by Swiss typography. Typography plays a huge role in the readability of complex data sets.
https://picsum.photos/id/3/800/600
content.caption: Final UI screens

content.content: The new dashboard has completely transformed how our users interact with their finances.
Lumina focuses on high-end fashion, so the app needed to feel invisible, letting the photography shine.

experience.description: Leading the design system team and overseeing core product UX.
Worked on various client projects ranging from fintech to healthcare.
Partnered with early-stage startups to define their MVP visuals.
Assisted in user research, wireframing, and usability testing for mobile applications.
Spearheading the UI overhaul for the next generation of enterprise tools.

config.heroDescription: Building digital products that blend aesthetics with function. Currently crafting experiences in San Francisco.
